text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with a quick cassoulet that's right
this classic french recipe usually takes
days to make but we've adapted a version
that's only gonna take about an hour and
is it gonna be as good no no it's not
but like i said it only takes about an
hour and it's actually pretty close i'm
going to start by throwing some thickly
sliced bacon into a dry pan on medium
heat and cook it till it's almost crisp
not quite but almost getting crisp and
this is kind of a one-dish meal so
you're going to want to choose sort of a
deep sided skillet like this it needs to
be able to go in the oven but something
that looks like this is perfect I'm
going to remove the bacon to a bowl but
I'm going to leave the bacon fat in the
pan because the next meat we're gonna
cook is our sausage so you're gonna want
to use something highly flavored I'm
using kind of a spicy garlicky smoked
sausage I believe it's officially a
Cajun sausage but pretty much any
sausage will work so we're going to cook
the sausage in the bacon fat for about
three or four minutes then we're going
to add our poultry which is usually
traditionally duck confit but we're just
going to use chicken thighs because this
like I said is a quick cassoulet so I
have chicken thigh that I've just cut in
large chunks I'm gonna saute that in
that bacon fat and sausage oil for about
five minutes until it looks like that
alright so now that we used all that
amazingly flavorful oil and bacon fat to
cook this stuff we're gonna get rid of
it so I'm going to remove the chunks of
meat and dump out all the oil in the pan
don't wipe the pan out just dump all the
oil off there'll be a tiny little bit of
grease on the bottom we're going to
throw in our chopped done in with a big
pinch of salt we're gonna turn the heat
down to medium-low and we're just going
to sweat our onion for about five
minutes I just want it to start to turn
translucent then we're going to deglaze
with some chicken broth and then we're
ready for the foundation of this entire
dish the beans alright so I have two
cans of white beans I believe those are
cannellini beans the Italian white beans
drain them rinse them and then before we
throw them in I'm going to smash about
25% of them just with a potato masher
just to break them up a little bit this
is going to help the texture of this
quick cassoulet kind of mimic the
texture of the original dish or
hopefully so stir in the beans I'm going
to add some cayenne pepper you know
because they usually do and then some
fresh herbs some rosemary and thyme very
very important we're going to dump the
reserve to meet back in the chicken the
sausage and the bacon and just enough
stock to cover about another cup alright
I'm going to turn the heat up to
medium-high and we're going to let that
simmer for about 5-6 minutes you can see
there it's pretty soupy but you're going
to be amazed at what happens here
alright while that's simmering I'm going
to make the breadcrumb mixture which is
the key to this super fast kind of
cheater method for cassoulet I have
melted butter plain breadcrumbs and real
Reggiano parmesan cheese I'm going to
mix that together and I'm going to
divide that in half we're going to do
this in two applications so our mixture
has been simmering on medium-high for
about five minutes I'm going to turn off
the heat and I'm going to sprinkle over
half our buttery Parmesan breadcrumbs
we're going to put that under a broiler
and we're going to broil that until
golden brown and crusty I'm about eight
inches below the heat so the traditional
cassoulet takes hours and hours and as
it cooks and every time a crust forms
you poke it down into the broth so we're
going to simulate that here so we're
just going to take a spoon and we're
going to push that beautiful buttery
caramelized crust down into the liquid
all right once it's mixed in we're going
to take the remaining breadcrumbs put
those over the top and then I'm just
going to poke it with the tip of my
spoon so it's kind of down in there a
little bit but mostly on the top that's
going to go back under the broiler until
that layer of breadcrumbs is beautifully
caramelized and golden brown and crusty
and amazing once the top is crusty I
want you to turn off the oven and just
leave it in the warm oven for 15 minutes
the beans will finish soaking up the
excess liquid so let it sit in the oven
for 15 minutes remember the ovens off
just keep the door closed
then pull it out let it sit for five
while you set the table and then dig in
to an amazing bean casserole think of
this as like pork and beans with
benefits pork and beans is great alright
but now we've introduced chicken and
sausage into the mix
that fresh rosemary and thyme I'm going
to have you put in really brings us all
together and then the trick we did
poking those buttery caramelized
breadcrumbs down into the broth really
helps simulate what you'd experience
with the longer much more involved
classic cassoulet anyway I hope you give
that a try like i joked it's not quite
as great as the original cassoulet but
it's still very very good and would
really make a great cold-weather meal so
head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts as usual and as
always enjoy
